description: From Anglo-Norman providence, Middle French providence, and their source, Latin prōvidentia (“providence, foresight”), from the present participle of prōvidēre (“to provide”). Displaced native Old English foresċēawung.

entries.meaning: (now rare) Preparation for the future; good governance, foresight. [from 14th c.]
The careful governance and guidance of God (or another deity, nature etc.). [from 14th c.]
A manifestation of divine care or direction; an instance of divine intervention. [from 16th c.]
examples: The idea was that a complete list of fully documented providences should be compiled as a cooperative venture which would cross denominational barriers.

entries.meaning: Specifically, the prudent care and management of resources; thriftiness, frugality. [from 17th c.]
examples: His providence in saving for his old age is exemplary.
